FEDERAL


Central Bank Reveals New Sandbox Conditions Regulations


On June 25, 2024, the Central Bank of the UAE issued the new “Sandbox Conditions Regulations” with the purpose of attracting startup and international fintech companies to the country.


Key features of these new regulations include:
- Testing innovative financial solutions to support the competitiveness of the UAE financial sector.
- Providing startups and fintechs with a suitable environment encouraging creativity and innovation.
- Exempting startups and fintechs from the requirement of obtaining a license for their services for a specific duration in order to test their creations and innovations.


New Law on Fair Competition


On July 11, 2024, the UAE issued a new Law promoting fair competition banning companies from applying below market low prices with the purpose of driving competitors out of business.

New Law on Fair Competition


On July 11, 2024, the UAE issued a new Law promoting fair competition banning companies from applying below market low prices with the purpose of driving competitors out of business.

Key features of this new law include:
- Competition definition as the act of conducting economic activities based on market mechanisms, but not such mechanisms that harmed trade, development and consumer interests.
- Regulates mergers and acquisitions in the country.
- Local authorities in the Emirates to conduct inspections to ensure compliance with this new Law.
- Complaints about unfair competition can be filed before the local authorities in the Emirates.
- Consumer protection from anti-competitive practices.


Dubai Chambers: Family Business Guiding Model


On 28 August 2024, the Dubai Family Business Centre of The Dubai Chambers issued a guiding model for family businesses.

A key feature of this guiding model includes, reviewing the family businesses’ administrative structures, specializations and regulatory frameworks and defining their activities and services.




ADGM


Whistleblower Protections with New ADGM 2024 Regulations


On July 5, 2024, the Abu Dhabi Global Market (“ADGM”) implemented The Employment Regulations (Amendment No. 1) 2024 and the Whistleblower Protection Regulations 2024 to enhance the protection of whistleblowers.

On July 5, 2024, the Abu Dhabi Global Market (“ADGM”) implemented The Employment Regulations (Amendment No. 1) 2024 and the Whistleblower Protection Regulations 2024 to enhance the protection of whistleblowers. 

Employers within the ADGM are required to implement the following Protected Disclosures processes by 31 May 2025:
- Facilitate persons to make protected disclosures.
- Assess and, where appropriate, escalate concerns arising from information received through a protected disclosure.
- Protect the identity of a person who makes a protected disclosure.

On July 23, 2024, the Council of Ministers approved the Oversight and Anti-Corruption Authority Law with the aim of strengthening the role of the Authority in combating corruption at both the financial and administrative levels in all its forms.

Key features of the new law include:
- Preserving public funds and protecting KSA’s capabilities.
- Ensuring accountability and prosecution of the violators.
- Defining the types of corruption which fall under the scope of the Authority including bribery, assault on public funds, abuse of power and any other crime classified as a corruption crime under the local laws.

Saudi Arabia Labour Law Amendments


The Ministry of Human Resources and Social Development (“MHRSD”) announced that the Saudi Labor Law of 2005 has overseen several amendments which will come into effect on 18 February 2025.

Key features of these new amendments include:
- Indefinite term employment agreements for non-Saudis changed to a one-year fixed term commencing on the date when employment started and renewed for the same period thereafter.
- Probation period of 180 days instead of 90 days
- Equal opportunities must be ensured by Employers with no discrimination on grounds of race, colour, sex, age, disability, marital status or any other form of discrimination.
- Notice period for a Saudi national to terminate their indefinite term contract reduced to 30 days
- Time off in lieu instead of overtime pay for any approved overtime can be agreed between the Employer and the Employee.
- A male employee will be entitled to three days’ paternity leave to be taken within seven days following childbirth.
- Three days’ bereavement leave will be granted for all employees following the death of a sibling. 
- Increase of the period of paid maternity leave for female employees to 12 weeks. It will remain mandatory to take six weeks of maternity leave following childbirth, and maternity leave can be taken no earlier than four weeks before the expected date of delivery.

Rules for Appointing Data Protection Officers


In line with Saudi Arabia Royal Decree No. M19/1443 <https://eur03.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.onechalhoub.com%2Fredir%2Ft%3Fs%3Dhttps%253a%252f%252fwww.lexismiddleeast.com%252flaw%252fSaudiArabia%252fRoyalDecree_M19_1443%252f%26t%3DU9SNiJg0GQTL7hVYOSWdyJuc%252fgGnWD4VMSwo7%252by4NfkA1kd2MqmJGffoONiqaUeTdgNvL4YBPB%252by%252fkAoxurgWe02h4FBHuvRAdEKNpiZINILFbPFeh%252fI94d27vKZofEDse8cjwJu6ZcIJhoKE3O0MenXvGmmFAjlU7zIIR4HFB2TiA5KSQhgkLCEtAeja%252ff%252bevtlX6Ff8%252fUxetO2yyZftK4qRwkd9mUFH7tbfNRY89P%252f5soSqVeevvugR6hXEtcoJlTYLzUayD6jq%252baFidyoCaEn%252fqUjr0rhvDO0NH6lTk0f2lbTvK8M5zwacmNMa2O6&data=05%7C02%7Chagop.ghazarian%40chalhoub.com%7C4b74ab6e4fe042dc6ddc08dce9d8eada%7C6ef8304cf37b42a5a5690a7d8249fbf3%7C0%7C0%7C638642365087068118%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C0%7C%7C%7C&sdata=L0UDnMujOQKGy14nFg3tehiQYeKEpn9li%2Bnd8Dafgjg%3D&reserved=0>  on the Approval of the Personal Data Protection Law and its amendments and implementing regulations, the Saudi Data & AI Authority (SDAIA) has issued new rules for appointing Personal Data Protection Officers (DPOs).

These new rules serve the purpose of developing and safeguarding personal data protection in Saudi Arabia by ensuring that qualified DPOs are appointed to oversee the implementation and compliance with these rules.

The appointment of DPOs, who can be employees of controllers or external contractors must be submitted to SDAIA and made accessible to data subjects.

Qatarisation New Law Approved


In September 2024, a draft law on Qatarisation requirements in the private sector became law and is expected to take effect in the next few months.

This Qatarisation new law, which aligns with Qatar National Vision 2030, aims at creating more career opportunities for Qatari nationals through enhancing their participation in private sector enterprises and companies.

This Qatarisation new law, which aligns with Qatar National Vision 2030, aims at creating more career opportunities for Qatari nationals through enhancing their participation in private sector enterprises and companies.

This new law applies to the following employers:
- Individuals managing private companies registered in the commercial register.
- Commercial companies operating in Qatar, whether State-owned, State-participated or privately owned.
- Private non-profit institutions, sports organisations, associations, and similar entities.

Key features of this new Law include:
- Providing financial incentives to the employers who fall under the new Qatarisation scheme, offering them various benefits, facilities, and privileges.
- Ensuring better career prospects for Qatari nationals through employment and training in accordance with the Labor Ministry’s policies, plans, and programs.

New Commercial License Requirements


On September 2, 2024 the Ministry of Commerce and Industry in Kuwait announced a new legal requirement for companies to disclose their ultimate beneficiary owner (UBO) also named in Kuwait as “actual beneficiary” through the commercial registry portal on the ministry’s website.

Failure to comply with this requirement will result in financial penalties and will be in contravention of other existing regulations on combating money laundering and terrorism financing.

Toughening Labour Market Regulations to Meet Omanisation Requirements


In July 2024, Oman’s Labour Ministry revealed a new set of strict labour market regulations aiming at favouring Omanisation in the private sector, which was implemented on September 2, 2024. 

They are marked by the following key features:
- Prohibition of government and state -owned companies from dealing with non-compliant companies.
- Expanding the list of jobs restricted for non-Omanis.
- Incentives for compliant companies and harsh penalties for non-compliant companies.
